<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Microsoft skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Microsoft</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Coord&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Coord (page does not exist)">Template:Coord</a>
{{#invoke:Infobox|infobox}}
</p><p><b>Microsoft Corporation</b> is an American <a href="/wiki/Multinational_corporation" title="Multinational corporation">multinational corporation</a> headquartered in <a href="/wiki/Redmond,_Washington" title="Redmond, Washington">Redmond</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Washington_(state)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Washington (state) (page does not exist)">Washington</a>, that develops, manufactures, licenses, supports and sells <a href="/w/index.php?title=Computer_software&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Computer software (page does not exist)">computer software</a>, <a href="/wiki/Consumer_electronics" title="Consumer electronics">consumer electronics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Personal_computers" title="Personal computers" class="mw-redirect">personal computers</a> and services. Its best known software products are the <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Windows" title="Microsoft Windows">Microsoft Windows</a> line of <a href="/wiki/Operating_systems" title="Operating systems" class="mw-redirect">operating systems</a>, <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Office" title="Microsoft Office">Microsoft Office</a> <a href="/wiki/Office_suite" title="Office suite">office suite</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Internet_Explorer" title="Internet Explorer">Internet Explorer</a> <a href="/wiki/Web_browser" title="Web browser">web browser</a>. Its flagship hardware products are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Xbox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xbox (page does not exist)">Xbox</a> game console and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Surface&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Surface (page does not exist)">Microsoft Surface</a> series of tablets. It is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_the_largest_software_companies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of the largest software companies (page does not exist)">world's largest software maker</a> measured by revenues.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> It is also one of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_corporations_by_market_capitalization&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of corporations by market capitalization (page does not exist)">world's most valuable companies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>Microsoft was founded by <a href="/wiki/Bill_Gates" title="Bill Gates">Bill Gates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paul_Allen" title="Paul Allen">Paul Allen</a> on April 4, 1975 to develop and sell <a href="/wiki/BASIC" title="BASIC">BASIC</a> <a href="/wiki/Interpreter_(computer_software)" title="Interpreter (computer software)" class="mw-redirect">interpreters</a> for <a href="/wiki/Altair_8800" title="Altair 8800">Altair 8800</a>. It rose to dominate the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Personal_computer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Personal computer (page does not exist)">personal computer</a> <a href="/wiki/Operating_system" title="Operating system">operating system</a> market with <a href="/w/index.php?title=MS-DOS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MS-DOS (page does not exist)">MS-DOS</a> in the mid-1980s, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Windows" title="Microsoft Windows">Microsoft Windows</a>. The company's 1986 <a href="/wiki/Initial_public_offering" title="Initial public offering">initial public offering</a>, and subsequent rise in its share price, created an estimated three billionaires and 12,000 millionaires from Microsoft employees. It is considered the third most successful startup company of all time by market capitalization, revenue, growth and cultural impact.<sup id="cite_ref-Top_20_Startups_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Top_20_Startups-3">[3]</a></sup>   Since the 1990s, it has increasingly diversified from the operating system market and has <a href="/wiki/List_of_mergers_and_acquisitions_by_Microsoft" title="List of mergers and acquisitions by Microsoft">made a number of corporate acquisitions</a>. In May 2011, Microsoft acquired <a href="/wiki/Skype_Technologies" title="Skype Technologies">Skype Technologies</a> for $8.5 billion in its largest acquisition to date.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2013, Microsoft is market dominant in both the <a href="/wiki/IBM_PC-compatible" title="IBM PC-compatible" class="mw-redirect">IBM PC-compatible</a> operating system and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Office_software_suite&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Office software suite (page does not exist)">office software suite</a> markets (the latter with <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Office" title="Microsoft Office">Microsoft Office</a>). The company also produces a wide range of other software for desktops and servers, and is active in areas including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Web_search_engine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Web search engine (page does not exist)">internet search</a> (with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bing (page does not exist)">Bing</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Video_game_industry" title="Video game industry">video game industry</a> (with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Xbox_(console)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xbox (console) (page does not exist)">Xbox</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Xbox_360&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xbox 360 (page does not exist)">Xbox 360</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Xbox_One&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xbox One (page does not exist)">Xbox One</a> consoles), the digital services market (through <a href="/wiki/MSN" title="MSN">MSN</a>), and mobile phones (via the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_Phone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows Phone (page does not exist)">Windows Phone</a> OS). In June 2012, Microsoft entered the personal computer production market for the first time, with the launch of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Surface&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Surface (page does not exist)">Microsoft Surface</a>, a line of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tablet_computer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tablet computer (page does not exist)">tablet computers</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1972.E2.80.9383:_Founding_and_company_beginnings">1972–83: Founding and company beginnings</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1981BillPaul.jpg" title="File:1981BillPaul.jpg">File:1981BillPaul.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Paul_Allen" title="Paul Allen">Paul Allen</a> (l.) and <a href="/wiki/Bill_Gates" title="Bill Gates">Bill Gates</a> (r.) on October 19, 1981, in a sea of PCs after signing a pivotal contract. IBM called Microsoft in July 1980 inquiring about <a href="/wiki/Programming_language" title="Programming language">programming languages</a> for its upcoming PC line;<sup id="cite_ref-Allan_2001_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Allan_2001-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> after failed negotiations with another company, IBM gave Microsoft a contract to develop the OS for the new line of PCs.<sup id="cite_ref-Smart-Microsoft_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Smart-Microsoft-6">[6]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Paul_Allen" title="Paul Allen">Paul Allen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bill_Gates" title="Bill Gates">Bill Gates</a>, childhood friends with a passion in <a href="/wiki/Computer_programming" title="Computer programming">computer programming</a>, were seeking to make a successful business utilizing their shared skills. In 1972 they founded their first company named <a href="/wiki/Traf-O-Data" title="Traf-O-Data">Traf-O-Data</a>, which offered a rudimentary computer that tracked and analyzed automobile traffic data. Allen went on to pursue a degree in computer science at the University of Washington, later dropping out of school to work at Honeywell. Gates began studies at Harvard.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>  The January 1975 issue of <i><a href="/wiki/Popular_Electronics" title="Popular Electronics">Popular Electronics</a></i> featured <a href="/wiki/Micro_Instrumentation_and_Telemetry_Systems" title="Micro Instrumentation and Telemetry Systems">Micro Instrumentation and Telemetry Systems</a>'s (MITS) <a href="/wiki/Altair_8800" title="Altair 8800">Altair 8800</a> <a href="/wiki/Microcomputer" title="Microcomputer">microcomputer</a>. Allen noticed that they could program a <a href="/wiki/BASIC" title="BASIC">BASIC</a> <a href="/wiki/Interpreter_(computing)" title="Interpreter (computing)">interpreter</a> for the device; after a call from Gates claiming to have a working interpreter, MITS requested a demonstration. Since they didn't actually have one, Allen worked on a <a href="/wiki/Simulation" title="Simulation">simulator</a> for the Altair while Gates developed the interpreter. Although they developed the interpreter on a simulator and not the actual device, the interpreter worked flawlessly when they demonstrated the interpreter to MITS in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Albuquerque&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Albuquerque (page does not exist)">Albuquerque</a>, New Mexico in March 1975; MITS agreed to distribute it, marketing it as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Altair_BASIC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Altair BASIC (page does not exist)">Altair BASIC</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Allan_2001_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Allan_2001-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> They officially established Microsoft on April 4, 1975, with Gates as the <a href="/wiki/Chief_executive_officer" title="Chief executive officer">CEO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BBCTL_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCTL-8">[8]</a></sup> Allen came up with the original name of "Micro-Soft," the combination of the words microcomputer and software, as recounted in a <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/1995/10/02/206528/index.htm">1995 Fortune magazine article</a>. In August 1977 the company formed an agreement with ASCII Magazine in Japan, resulting in its first international office, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=ASCII_(company)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ASCII (company) (page does not exist)">ASCII Microsoft</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> The company moved to a new home in <a href="/wiki/Bellevue,_Washington" title="Bellevue, Washington">Bellevue, Washington</a> in January 1979.<sup id="cite_ref-BBCTL_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCTL-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>Microsoft entered the OS business in 1980 with its own version of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Unix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unix (page does not exist)">Unix</a>, called <a href="/wiki/Xenix" title="Xenix">Xenix</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> However, it was <a href="/w/index.php?title=MS-DOS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MS-DOS (page does not exist)">MS-DOS</a> that solidified the company's dominance. After negotiations with <a href="/wiki/Digital_Research" title="Digital Research">Digital Research</a> failed, <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Business_Machines&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Business Machines (page does not exist)">IBM</a> awarded a contract to Microsoft in November 1980 to provide a version of the <a href="/wiki/CP/M" title="CP/M">CP/M</a> OS, which was set to be used in the upcoming <a href="/wiki/IBM_Personal_Computer" title="IBM Personal Computer">IBM Personal Computer</a> (IBM PC).<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> For this deal, Microsoft purchased a CP/M clone called <a href="/wiki/86-DOS" title="86-DOS">86-DOS</a> from <a href="/wiki/Seattle_Computer_Products" title="Seattle Computer Products">Seattle Computer Products</a>, branding it as MS-DOS, which IBM rebranded to <a href="/wiki/PC_DOS" title="PC DOS" class="mw-redirect">PC DOS</a>. Following the release of the IBM PC in August 1981, Microsoft retained ownership of MS-DOS. Since IBM <a href="/wiki/Copyright" title="Copyright">copyrighted</a> the IBM PC <a href="/wiki/BIOS" title="BIOS">BIOS</a>, other companies had to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reverse_engineering&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reverse engineering (page does not exist)">reverse engineer</a> it in order for non-IBM hardware to run as <a href="/wiki/IBM_PC_compatible" title="IBM PC compatible">IBM PC compatibles</a>, but no such restriction applied to the operating systems. Due to various factors, such as MS-DOS's available software selection, Microsoft eventually became the leading PC operating systems vendor.<sup id="cite_ref-Smart-Microsoft_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Smart-Microsoft-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Blaxill_Eckardt_2009_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Blaxill_Eckardt_2009-12">[12]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> The company expanded into new markets with the release of the <i>Microsoft Mouse</i> in 1983, as well as a publishing division named <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Press&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Press (page does not exist)">Microsoft Press</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Allan_2001_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Allan_2001-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Paul Allen resigned from Microsoft in February after developing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hodgkin%27s_lymphoma&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hodgkin's lymphoma (page does not exist)">Hodgkin's disease</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Allan_2001_5-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Allan_2001-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1984.E2.80.9394:_Windows_and_Office">1984–94: Windows and Office</span></h3>
<p>While jointly developing a new OS with IBM in 1984, <a href="/wiki/OS/2" title="OS/2">OS/2</a>, Microsoft released <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Windows" title="Microsoft Windows">Microsoft Windows</a>, a graphical extension for MS-DOS, on November 20, 1985.<sup id="cite_ref-Allan_2001_5-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Allan_2001-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Microsoft moved its headquarters to Redmond on February 26, 1986, and on March 13 the company went <a href="/wiki/Public_company" title="Public company">public</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-CBSCHRON_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBSCHRON-13">[13]</a></sup> the ensuing rise in the stock would make an estimated four billionaires and 12,000 millionaires from Microsoft employees.<sup id="cite_ref-stockrich_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stockrich-14">[14]</a></sup> Due to the partnership with IBM, in 1990 the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Trade_Commission" title="Federal Trade Commission">Federal Trade Commission</a> set its eye on Microsoft for possible <a href="/wiki/Collusion" title="Collusion">collusion</a>; it marked the beginning of over a decade of legal clashes with the U.S. Government.<sup id="cite_ref-WiredUSDOJ_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WiredUSDOJ-15">[15]</a></sup> Microsoft announced the release of its version of OS/2 to <a href="/wiki/Original_equipment_manufacturer" title="Original equipment manufacturer">original equipment manufacturers</a> (OEMs) on April 2, 1987;<sup id="cite_ref-Allan_2001_5-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Allan_2001-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> meanwhile, the company was at work on a <a href="/wiki/32-bit" title="32-bit">32-bit</a> OS, <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Windows_NT" title="Microsoft Windows NT" class="mw-redirect">Microsoft Windows NT</a>, using ideas from OS/2; it shipped on July 21, 1993, with a new <a href="/wiki/Modular_programming" title="Modular programming">modular</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kernel_(computing)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kernel (computing) (page does not exist)">kernel</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Windows_API" title="Windows API">Win32</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Application_programming_interface&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Application programming interface (page does not exist)">application programming interface</a> (API), making <a href="/wiki/Porting" title="Porting">porting</a> from <a href="/w/index.php?title=16-bit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="16-bit (page does not exist)">16-bit</a> (MS-DOS-based) Windows easier. Once Microsoft informed IBM of NT, the OS/2 partnership deteriorated.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1990, Microsoft introduced its office suite, <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Office" title="Microsoft Office">Microsoft Office</a>. The software bundled separate office productivity applications, such as <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Word" title="Microsoft Word">Microsoft Word</a> and <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Excel" title="Microsoft Excel">Microsoft Excel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Allan_2001_5-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Allan_2001-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> On May 22 Microsoft launched <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_3.0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows 3.0 (page does not exist)">Windows 3.0</a> with a streamlined <a href="/wiki/User_interface" title="User interface">user interface</a> graphics and improved <a href="/wiki/Protected_mode" title="Protected mode">protected mode</a> capability for the <a href="/wiki/Intel_80386" title="Intel 80386">Intel 386</a> processor.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> Both Office and Windows became dominant in their respective areas.<sup id="cite_ref-1993-2001_market_share_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1993-2001_market_share-18">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Novell" title="Novell">Novell</a>, a Word competitor from 1984–1986, filed a lawsuit years later claiming that Microsoft left part of its APIs undocumented in order to gain a competitive advantage.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>On July 27, 1994, the U.S. Department of Justice, Antitrust Division filed a Competitive Impact Statement that said, in part:
"Beginning in 1988, and continuing until July 15, 1994, Microsoft induced many OEMs to execute anti-competitive "per processor" licenses. Under a per processor license, an OEM pays Microsoft a royalty for each computer it sells containing a particular microprocessor, whether the OEM sells the computer with a Microsoft operating system or a non-Microsoft operating system. In effect, the royalty payment to Microsoft when no Microsoft product is being used acts as a penalty, or tax, on the OEM's use of a competing PC operating system. Since 1988, Microsoft's use of per processor licenses has increased."<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1995.E2.80.932005:_Internet_and_the_32-bit_era">1995–2005: Internet and the 32-bit era</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bill_Gates_-_United_States_v._Microsoft.jpg" title="File:Bill Gates - United States v. Microsoft.jpg">File:Bill Gates - United States v. Microsoft.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Bill Gates giving his deposition in 1998 for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_v._Microsoft&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States v. Microsoft (page does not exist)">United States v. Microsoft</a> trial. Once the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Justice" title="U.S. Department of Justice" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Department of Justice</a> 1993 took over from the Federal Trade Commission, a protracted legal wrangling between Microsoft and the department ensued, resulting in various settlements and possible blocked mergers. Microsoft would point to companies such as <a href="/wiki/Time_Warner" title="Time Warner">AOL-Time Warner</a> in its defense.<sup id="cite_ref-WiredUSDOJ_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WiredUSDOJ-15">[15]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Following Bill Gates's internal "Internet Tidal Wave memo" on May 26, 1995, Microsoft began to redefine its offerings and expand its product line into <a href="/w/index.php?title=Computer_network&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Computer network (page does not exist)">computer networking</a> and the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Web" title="World Wide Web">World Wide Web</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> The company released <a href="/wiki/Windows_95" title="Windows 95">Windows 95</a> on August 24, 1995, featuring <a href="/wiki/Pre-emptive_multitasking" title="Pre-emptive multitasking" class="mw-redirect">pre-emptive multitasking</a>, a completely new user interface with a novel <a href="/wiki/Start_menu" title="Start menu">start button</a>, and 32-bit compatibility; similar to NT, it provided the Win32 API.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Pietrek_1996_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pietrek_1996-24">[24]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a> Windows 95 came bundled with the <a href="/wiki/Online_service" title="Online service" class="mw-redirect">online service</a> <a href="/wiki/MSN" title="MSN">MSN</a>, and for OEMs <a href="/wiki/Internet_Explorer" title="Internet Explorer">Internet Explorer</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Web_browser" title="Web browser">web browser</a>. Internet Explorer was not bundled with the retail Windows 95 boxes because the boxes were printed before the team finished the web browser, and instead was included in the Windows 95 Plus! pack.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> Branching out into new markets in 1996, Microsoft and <a href="/w/index.php?title=NBC_Universal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NBC Universal (page does not exist)">NBC Universal</a> created a new <a href="/w/index.php?title=24/7&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="24/7 (page does not exist)">24/7</a> cable news station, <a href="/wiki/MSNBC" title="MSNBC">MSNBC</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-APM-NewsArchives_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-APM-NewsArchives-26">[26]</a></sup> Microsoft created <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_CE_1.0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows CE 1.0 (page does not exist)">Windows CE 1.0</a>, a new OS designed for devices with low memory and other constraints, such as <a href="/wiki/Personal_digital_assistant" title="Personal digital assistant">personal digital assistants</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cehistory_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cehistory-27">[27]</a></sup> In October 1997, the Justice Department filed a motion in the Federal <a href="/wiki/United_States_district_court" title="United States district court">District Court</a>, stating that Microsoft violated an agreement signed in 1994 and asked the court to stop the bundling of Internet Explorer with Windows.<sup id="cite_ref-Allan_2001_5-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Allan_2001-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a>
</p><p>Bill Gates handed over the CEO position on January 13, 2000, to <a href="/wiki/Steve_Ballmer" title="Steve Ballmer">Steve Ballmer</a>, an old college friend of Gates and employee of the company since 1980, creating a new position for himself as Chief <a href="/w/index.php?title=Software_architect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Software architect (page does not exist)">Software Architect</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Allan_2001_5-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Allan_2001-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a><sup id="cite_ref-BBCTL_8-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCTL-8">[8]</a></sup> Various companies including Microsoft formed the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trusted_Computing_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trusted Computing Group (page does not exist)">Trusted Computing Platform Alliance</a> in October 1999 to, among other things, increase security and protect <a href="/wiki/Intellectual_property" title="Intellectual property">intellectual property</a> through identifying changes in hardware and software. Critics decry the alliance as a way to enforce indiscriminate restrictions over how consumers use software, and over how computers behave, a form of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Digital_rights_management&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Digital rights management (page does not exist)">digital rights management</a>; for example the scenario where a computer is not only secured for its owner, but also secured against its owner as well.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> On April 3, 2000, a judgment was handed down in the case of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_v._Microsoft&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States v. Microsoft (page does not exist)">United States v. Microsoft</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-usvms_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-usvms-30">[30]</a></sup> calling the company an "abusive monopoly";<sup id="cite_ref-findingsoffact_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-findingsoffact-31">[31]</a></sup> it settled with the U.S. Department of Justice in 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-CBSCHRON_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBSCHRON-13">[13]</a></sup> On October 25, 2001, Microsoft released <a href="/wiki/Windows_XP" title="Windows XP">Windows XP</a>, unifying the mainstream and NT lines under the NT codebase.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> The company released the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Xbox_(console)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xbox (console) (page does not exist)">Xbox</a> later that year, entering the <a href="/wiki/Game_console" title="Game console" class="mw-redirect">game console</a> market dominated by <a href="/wiki/Sony" title="Sony">Sony</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nintendo" title="Nintendo">Nintendo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BizWire-2001Ent_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BizWire-2001Ent-33">[33]</a></sup> In March 2004 the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> brought <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_Union_Microsoft_antitrust_case&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European Union Microsoft antitrust case (page does not exist)">antitrust legal action against the company</a>, citing it abused its dominance with the Windows OS, resulting in a judgment of €497<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nbsp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nbsp (page does not exist)">Template:Nbspmillion</a> ($613<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nbsp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nbsp (page does not exist)">Template:Nbspmillion</a>) and to produce new versions of Windows XP without <a href="/wiki/Windows_Media_Player" title="Windows Media Player">Windows Media Player</a>, Windows XP Home Edition N and Windows XP Professional N.<sup id="cite_ref-CNN-MSfine_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-MSfine-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-euantitrust_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euantitrust-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2006.E2.80.9310:_Windows_Vista.2C_mobile.2C_and_Windows_7">2006–10: Windows Vista, mobile, and Windows 7</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Steve_Ballmer_-_MIX_2008.jpg" title="File:Steve Ballmer - MIX 2008.jpg">File:Steve Ballmer - MIX 2008.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">CEO <a href="/wiki/Steve_Ballmer" title="Steve Ballmer">Steve Ballmer</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=MIX_(Microsoft)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MIX (Microsoft) (page does not exist)">MIX</a> event in 2008. In an interview about his management style in 2005, he mentioned that his first priority was to get the people he <a href="/wiki/Delegate" title="Delegate">delegates</a> to in order. Ballmer also emphasized the need to continue pursuing new technologies even if initial attempts fail, citing the original attempts with Windows as an example.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Released in January 2007, the next version of Windows, <a href="/wiki/Windows_Vista" title="Windows Vista">Windows Vista</a>, focused on features, security, and a redesigned user interface dubbed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_Aero&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows Aero (page does not exist)">Aero</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-gatesrsa_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gatesrsa-38">[38]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Office_2007&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Office 2007 (page does not exist)">Microsoft Office 2007</a>, released at the same time, featured a "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Ribbon_(computing)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ribbon (computing) (page does not exist)">Ribbon</a>" user interface which was a significant departure from its predecessors. Relatively strong sales of both titles helped to produce a record profit in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> The European Union imposed another fine of €899<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nbsp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nbsp (page does not exist)">Template:Nbspmillion</a> ($1.4<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nbsp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nbsp (page does not exist)">Template:Nbspbillion</a>) for Microsoft's lack of compliance with the March 2004 judgment on February 27, 2008, saying that the company charged rivals unreasonable prices for key information about its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_SQL_Server&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft SQL Server (page does not exist)">workgroup</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_BackOffice_Server&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft BackOffice Server (page does not exist)">backoffice</a> servers. Microsoft stated that it was in compliance and that "these fines are about the past issues that have been resolved".<sup id="cite_ref-msft_eufine_2008_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-msft_eufine_2008-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>2007 also saw the creation of a multi-core unit at Microsoft, as they followed in the steps of server companies such as Sun and IBM.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bill Gates retired from his role as Chief Software Architect on June 27, 2008, while retaining other positions related to the company in addition to being an advisor for the company on key projects.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Azure_Services_Platform&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Azure Services Platform (page does not exist)">Azure Services Platform</a>, the company's entry into the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cloud_computing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cloud computing (page does not exist)">cloud computing</a> market for Windows, launched on October 27, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> On February 12, 2009, Microsoft announced its intent to open a chain of Microsoft-branded retail stores, and on October 22, 2009, the first retail <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Store&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Store (page does not exist)">Microsoft Store</a> opened in <a href="/wiki/Scottsdale,_Arizona" title="Scottsdale, Arizona">Scottsdale</a>, Arizona; the same day the first store opened, <a href="/wiki/Windows_7" title="Windows 7">Windows 7</a> was officially released to the public. Windows 7's focus was on refining Vista with ease of use features and performance enhancements, rather than a large reworking of Windows.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>As the smartphone industry boomed beginning in 2007, Microsoft struggled to keep up with its rivals <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple</a> and <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a> in providing a modern smartphone operating system. As a result, in 2010, Microsoft revamped their aging flagship mobile operating system, <a href="/wiki/Windows_Mobile" title="Windows Mobile">Windows Mobile</a>, replacing it with the new <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_Phone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows Phone (page does not exist)">Windows Phone</a> OS; along with a new strategy in the smartphone industry that has Microsoft working more closely with smartphone manufacturers, such as <a href="/wiki/Nokia" title="Nokia">Nokia</a>, and to provide a consistent user experience across all smartphones using Microsoft's Windows Phone OS. It used a new user interface design language, codenamed "Metro", which prominently used simple shapes, typography and iconography, and the concept of minimalism.
</p><p>Microsoft is a founding member of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Open_Networking_Foundation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Open Networking Foundation (page does not exist)">Open Networking Foundation</a> started on March 23, 2011. Other founding companies include <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=HP_Networking&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="HP Networking (page does not exist)">HP Networking</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yahoo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yahoo (page does not exist)">Yahoo</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Verizon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Verizon (page does not exist)">Verizon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deutsche_Telekom" title="Deutsche Telekom">Deutsche Telekom</a> and 17 other companies. The nonprofit organization is focused on providing support for a new <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cloud_computing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cloud computing (page does not exist)">cloud computing</a> initiative called Software-Defined Networking.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> The initiative is meant to speed innovation through simple software changes in telecommunications networks, wireless networks, data centers and other networking areas.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2011.E2.80.93present:_Rebranding.2C_Windows_8.2C_and_Surface">2011–present: Rebranding, Windows 8, and Surface</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Windows_8_Start_UI.svg" title="File:Windows 8 Start UI.svg">File:Windows 8 Start UI.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">General design principle behind <a href="/w/index.php?title=Start_screen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Start screen (page does not exist)">Start screen</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_8&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows 8 (page does not exist)">Windows 8</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_Phone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows Phone (page does not exist)">Windows Phone</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Xbox_One&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xbox One (page does not exist)">Xbox One</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Microsoft_Surface_(black).jpg" title="File:Microsoft Surface (black).jpg">File:Microsoft Surface (black).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Surface&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Surface (page does not exist)">Microsoft Surface</a> tablet</div></div></div>
<p>Following the release of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_Phone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows Phone (page does not exist)">Windows Phone</a>, Microsoft underwent a gradual <a href="/wiki/Rebranding" title="Rebranding">rebranding</a> of its product range throughout 2011 and 2012—the corporation's logos, products, services, and websites adopted the principles and concepts of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Metro_(design_language)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metro (design language) (page does not exist)">Metro design language</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-WindowsPhone7UI_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WindowsPhone7UI-49">[49]</a></sup> Microsoft previewed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_8&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows 8 (page does not exist)">Windows 8</a>, an operating system designed to power both personal computers and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tablet_computer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tablet computer (page does not exist)">tablet computers</a>, in Taipei in June 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> A developer preview was released on September 13, and was replaced by a consumer preview on February 29, 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> On May 31, 2012, the preview version was released.
</p><p>On June 18, 2012, Microsoft announced the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Surface&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Surface (page does not exist)">Microsoft Surface</a>, the first computer in the company's history to have its hardware made by Microsoft.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-VF2012_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VF2012-53">[53]</a></sup> On June 25, Microsoft announced that it was paying US$1.2 billion to buy the social network <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yammer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yammer (page does not exist)">Yammer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> On July 31, 2012, Microsoft launched the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Outlook.com&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Outlook.com (page does not exist)">Outlook.com</a> <a href="/wiki/Webmail" title="Webmail">webmail service</a> to compete with <a href="/wiki/Gmail" title="Gmail">Gmail</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> On September 4, 2012, Microsoft released <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_Server_2012&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows Server 2012 (page does not exist)">Windows Server 2012</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MSofficialRTM_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSofficialRTM-56">[56]</a></sup> On October 1, Microsoft announced its intention to launch a news operation, part of a new-look <a href="/wiki/MSN" title="MSN">MSN</a>, at the time of the Windows 8 launch that was later in the month.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> On October 26, 2012, Microsoft launched Windows 8 and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Surface&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Surface (page does not exist)">Microsoft Surface</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-VF2012_53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VF2012-53">[53]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> Three days later, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_Phone_8&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows Phone 8 (page does not exist)">Windows Phone 8</a> was launched.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> To cope with the potential for an increase in demand for products and services, Microsoft opened a number of "holiday stores" across the U.S. to complement the increasing number of "bricks-and-mortar" Microsoft Stores that opened in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 29, 2013, Microsoft launched a Patent Tracker.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kinect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kinect (page does not exist)">Kinect</a> sensor device was upgraded for the 2013 release of the eighth-generation <a href="/w/index.php?title=Xbox_One&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xbox One (page does not exist)">Xbox One</a> and its capabilities were revealed in May 2013. The new Kinect uses an ultra-wide 1080p camera, it can function in the dark due to an infrared sensor, it employs higher-end processing power and new software, it can distinguish between fine movements (such as a thumb movements), and the device can determine a user's heart rate by looking at his/her face.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> Microsoft filed a patent application in 2011 that suggests that the corporation may use the Kinect camera system to monitor the behavior of television viewers as part of a plan to make the viewing experience more active.On July 19, 2013, Microsoft stocks suffered its biggest one-day percentage sell-off since the year 2000 after its fourth-quarter report raised concerns among the investors on the poor showings of both Windows 8 and the Surface tablet; with more than 11 percentage points declining Microsoft suffered a loss of more than USD 32billion.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> For the 2010 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fiscal_year&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fiscal year (page does not exist)">fiscal year</a>, Microsoft had five product divisions: Windows Division, Server and Tools, Online Services Division, Microsoft Business Division, and Entertainment and Devices Division.
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional" style="text-align:center;">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Xbox One console and controller at Gamescom 2013.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Xbox_One&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xbox One (page does not exist)">Xbox One</a> console
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Xbox-360-Kinect-Standalone.png</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Kinect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kinect (page does not exist)">Kinect</a> controller
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
</ul>
<p>On September 3, 2013, Microsoft agreed to buy <a href="/wiki/Nokia" title="Nokia">Nokia</a>'s mobile unit for $7 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> Also in 2013, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amy_Hood&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amy Hood (page does not exist)">Amy Hood</a> became the CFO of Microsoft.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>Microsoft's current <a href="/wiki/Chief_executive_officer" title="Chief executive officer">CEO</a> is <a href="/wiki/Steve_Ballmer" title="Steve Ballmer">Steve Ballmer</a>, who is set to retire within twelve months after August 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Alliance for Affordable Internet (A4AI) was launched in October 2013 and Microsoft is part of the coalition of public and private organizations that also includes <a href="/w/index.php?title=Facebook&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Facebook (page does not exist)">Facebook</a>, <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">Intel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a>. Led by <a href="/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee" title="Tim Berners-Lee">Tim Berners-Lee</a>, the A4AI seeks to make Internet access more affordable so that access is broadened in the developing world, where only 31% of people are online. Google will help to decrease internet access prices so that they fall below the UN Broadband Commission's worldwide target of 5% of monthly income.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>In line with the maturing PC business, in July 2013 Microsoft announced to reorganize the business into 4 new business divisions by function: Operating System, Apps, Cloud and Devices. All previous divisions will be diluted into new divisions without any workforce cut.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Businesses">Businesses</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Windows_Division.2C_Server_and_Tools.2C_Online_Services_Division">Windows Division, Server and Tools, Online Services Division</span></h3>
<p>The company's Client division produces the flagship Windows OS line such as Windows 8; it also produces the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_Live&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows Live (page does not exist)">Windows Live</a> family of products and services. Server and Tools produces the server versions of Windows, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_Server_2008_R2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows Server 2008 R2 (page does not exist)">Windows Server 2008 R2</a> as well as a set of development tools called <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Visual_Studio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Visual Studio (page does not exist)">Microsoft Visual Studio</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Silverlight&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Silverlight (page does not exist)">Microsoft Silverlight</a>, a web application framework, and <a href="/wiki/System_Center_Configuration_Manager" title="System Center Configuration Manager">System Center Configuration Manager</a>, a collection of tools providing remote-control abilities, patch management, software distribution and a hardware/software inventory. Other server products include: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_SQL_Server&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft SQL Server (page does not exist)">Microsoft SQL Server</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Relational_database" title="Relational database">relational database</a> management system, <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Exchange_Server" title="Microsoft Exchange Server">Microsoft Exchange Server</a>, for certain business-oriented <a href="/w/index.php?title=E-mail&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="E-mail (page does not exist)">e-mail</a> and scheduling features, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_Small_Business_Server&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows Small Business Server (page does not exist)">Small Business Server</a>, for messaging and other small business-oriented features; and <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_BizTalk_Server" title="Microsoft BizTalk Server">Microsoft BizTalk Server</a>, for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Business_process_management&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Business process management (page does not exist)">business process management</a>.
</p><p>Microsoft provides <a href="/w/index.php?title=Information_technology_consulting&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Information technology consulting (page does not exist)">IT consulting</a> ("Microsoft Consulting Services") and produces a set of certification programs handled by the Server and Tools division designed to recognize individuals who have a minimal set of proficiencies in a specific role; this includes developers (<a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Certified_Professional" title="Microsoft Certified Professional">"Microsoft Certified Solution Developer"</a>), system/network analysts (<a href="/w/index.php?title=MCSE&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MCSE (page does not exist)">"Microsoft Certified Systems Engineer"</a>), trainers ("<a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Certified_Professional" title="Microsoft Certified Professional">Microsoft Certified Trainers</a>") and administrators ("<a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Certified_Systems_Administrator" title="Microsoft Certified Systems Administrator" class="mw-redirect">Microsoft Certified Systems Administrator</a>" and <a href="/wiki/MCDBA" title="MCDBA" class="mw-redirect">"Microsoft Certified Database Administrator"</a>). <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Press&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Press (page does not exist)">Microsoft Press</a>, which publishes books, is also managed by the division. The Online Services Business division handles the online service <a href="/wiki/MSN" title="MSN">MSN</a> and the search engine <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bing (page does not exist)">Bing</a>. As of December 2009, the company also possesses an 18% ownership of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cable_news&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cable news (page does not exist)">cable news</a> channel <a href="/wiki/MSNBC" title="MSNBC">MSNBC</a> without any editorial control; however, the division develops the channel's website, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Msnbc.com&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Msnbc.com (page does not exist)">msnbc.com</a>, in a <a href="/wiki/Joint_venture" title="Joint venture">joint venture</a> with the channel's co-owner, <a href="/w/index.php?title=NBC_Universal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NBC Universal (page does not exist)">NBC Universal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MSNBC_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSNBC-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Business_Division">Business Division</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Microsoft_Commons.jpg" title="File:The Microsoft Commons.jpg">File:The Microsoft Commons.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Commons, located on the campus of the company's headquarters in Redmond</div></div></div>
<p>The Microsoft Business Division produces <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Office" title="Microsoft Office">Microsoft Office</a> including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Office_2010&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Office 2010 (page does not exist)">Microsoft Office 2010</a>, the company's line of office software. The software product includes <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Office_Word&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Office Word (page does not exist)">Word</a> (a word processor), <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Access" title="Microsoft Access">Access</a> (a <a href="/wiki/Relational_database" title="Relational database">relational database</a> program), <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Excel" title="Microsoft Excel">Excel</a> (a <a href="/wiki/Spreadsheet" title="Spreadsheet">spreadsheet</a> program), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Office_Outlook&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Office Outlook (page does not exist)">Outlook</a> (<a href="/wiki/Collaborative_software" title="Collaborative software">Groupware</a>, frequently used with <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Exchange_Server" title="Microsoft Exchange Server">Exchange Server</a>), <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_PowerPoint" title="Microsoft PowerPoint">PowerPoint</a> (presentation software), <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Publisher" title="Microsoft Publisher">Publisher</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Desktop_publishing_software&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Desktop publishing software (page does not exist)">desktop publishing software</a>) and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Sharepoint&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Sharepoint (page does not exist)">Sharepoint</a>. A number of other products were added later with the release of Office 2003 including <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Visio" title="Microsoft Visio">Visio</a>, <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Project" title="Microsoft Project">Project</a>, <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_MapPoint" title="Microsoft MapPoint">MapPoint</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_InfoPath&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft InfoPath (page does not exist)">InfoPath</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Office_OneNote&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Office OneNote (page does not exist)">OneNote</a>. The division also develops <a href="/wiki/Enterprise_resource_planning" title="Enterprise resource planning">enterprise resource planning</a> (ERP) software for companies under the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Dynamics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Dynamics (page does not exist)">Microsoft Dynamics</a> brand. These include: <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Dynamics_AX" title="Microsoft Dynamics AX">Microsoft Dynamics AX</a>, <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Dynamics_NAV" title="Microsoft Dynamics NAV">Microsoft Dynamics NAV</a>, <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Dynamics_GP" title="Microsoft Dynamics GP">Microsoft Dynamics GP</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Dynamics_SL&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Dynamics SL (page does not exist)">Microsoft Dynamics SL</a>. They are targeted at varying company types and countries, and limited to organizations with under 7,500 employees.<sup id="cite_ref-MS_Dynamics_Lineup_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MS_Dynamics_Lineup-70">[70]</a></sup> Also included under the Dynamics brand is the <a href="/wiki/Customer_relationship_management" title="Customer relationship management">customer relationship management</a> software <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Dynamics_CRM&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Dynamics CRM (page does not exist)">Microsoft Dynamics CRM</a>, part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Azure_Services_Platform&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Azure Services Platform (page does not exist)">Azure Services Platform</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Entertainment_and_Devices_Division">Entertainment and Devices Division</span></h3>
<p>The Entertainment and Devices Division produces the <a href="/wiki/Windows_CE" title="Windows CE">Windows CE</a> OS for <a href="/wiki/Embedded_system" title="Embedded system">embedded systems</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Windows_Phone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Windows Phone (page does not exist)">Windows Phone</a> for <a href="/wiki/Smartphone" title="Smartphone">smartphones</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> Microsoft initially entered the mobile market through Windows CE for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Handheld_device&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Handheld device (page does not exist)">handheld devices</a>, eventually developing into the <a href="/wiki/Windows_Mobile" title="Windows Mobile">Windows Mobile</a> OS and now, Windows Phone. Windows CE is designed for devices where the OS may not directly be visible to the end user, in particular, appliances and cars. The division also produces <a href="/wiki/Computer_games" title="Computer games" class="mw-redirect">computer games</a> that run on Windows PCs and other systems including titles such as <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Empires" title="Age of Empires">Age of Empires</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Halo_(video_game_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Halo (video game series) (page does not exist)">Halo</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Flight_Simulator" title="Microsoft Flight Simulator">Microsoft Flight Simulator</a> series, and houses the <a href="/wiki/Macintosh_Business_Unit" title="Macintosh Business Unit">Macintosh Business Unit</a> which produces <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mac_OS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mac OS (page does not exist)">Mac OS</a> software including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_Office_2011_for_Mac&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft Office 2011 for Mac (page does not exist)">Microsoft Office 2011 for Mac</a>. Microsoft's Entertainment and Devices Division designs, markets, and manufactures <a href="/wiki/Consumer_electronics" title="Consumer electronics">consumer electronics</a> including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Xbox_360&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xbox 360 (page does not exist)">Xbox 360</a> game console, the handheld <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zune&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zune (page does not exist)">Zune</a> media player, and the television-based <a href="/wiki/Internet_appliance" title="Internet appliance">Internet appliance</a> <a href="/wiki/MSN_TV" title="MSN TV">MSN TV</a>. Microsoft also markets <a href="/wiki/Personal_computer_hardware" title="Personal computer hardware" class="mw-redirect">personal computer hardware</a> including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Computer_mouse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Computer mouse (page does not exist)">mice</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Computer_keyboard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Computer keyboard (page does not exist)">keyboards</a>, and various <a href="/wiki/Game_controller" title="Game controller">game controllers</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Joystick" title="Joystick">joysticks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gamepad" title="Gamepad">gamepads</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<p>Technical reference for developers and articles for various Microsoft magazines such as <i>Microsoft Systems Journal</i> (MSJ) are available through the <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Developer_Network" title="Microsoft Developer Network">Microsoft Developer Network</a> (MSDN). MSDN also offers subscriptions for companies and individuals, and the more expensive subscriptions usually offer access to pre-release beta versions of Microsoft software.<sup id="cite_ref-MSDN-SubscribeFAQ_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSDN-SubscribeFAQ-72">[72]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MSJ-home_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSJ-home-73">[73]</a></sup> In April 2004 Microsoft launched a community site for developers and users, titled <a href="/w/index.php?title=Channel9&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Channel9 (page does not exist)">Channel9</a>, that provides a <a href="/wiki/Wiki" title="Wiki">wiki</a> and an <a href="/wiki/Internet_forum" title="Internet forum">Internet forum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Hobson_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hobson-74">[74]</a></sup> Another community site that provides daily <a href="/wiki/Videocast" title="Videocast" class="mw-redirect">videocasts</a> and other services, On10.net, launched on March 3, 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-On10-home_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-On10-home-75">[75]</a></sup> Free technical support is traditionally provided through online <a href="/w/index.php?title=Usenet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Usenet (page does not exist)">Usenet</a> newsgroups, and <a href="/wiki/CompuServe" title="CompuServe">CompuServe</a> in the past, monitored by Microsoft employees; there can be several newsgroups for a single product. Helpful people can be elected by peers or Microsoft employees for <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Most_Valuable_Professional" title="Microsoft Most Valuable Professional">Microsoft Most Valuable Professional</a> (MVP) status, which entitles them to a sort of special social status and possibilities for awards and other benefits.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>Noted for its internal <a href="/wiki/Lexicon" title="Lexicon">lexicon</a>, the expression <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eat_one%27s_own_dog_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eat one's own dog food (page does not exist)">"eating our own dog food"</a> is used to describe the policy of using pre-release and beta versions of products inside Microsoft in an effort to test them in "real-world" situations.<sup id="cite_ref-dogfood_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dogfood-77">[77]</a></sup> This is usually shortened to just "dog food" and is used as noun, verb, and adjective. Another bit of <a href="/wiki/Jargon" title="Jargon">jargon</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=FYIFV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FYIFV (page does not exist)">FYIFV</a> or FYIV ("Fuck You, I'm [Fully] Vested"), is used by an employee to indicate they are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Financial_independence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Financial independence (page does not exist)">financially independent</a> and can avoid work anytime they wish.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> The company is also known for its hiring process, mimicked in other organizations and dubbed the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Microsoft_interview&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microsoft interview (page does not exist)">Microsoft interview</a>", which is notorious for off-the-wall questions such as "Why is a <a href="/wiki/Manhole_cover" title="Manhole cover">manhole cover</a> round?".<sup id="cite_ref-manhole_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-manhole-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>Microsoft is an outspoken opponent of the cap on <a href="/wiki/H1B_visa" title="H1B visa" class="mw-redirect">H1B visas</a>, which allow companies in the U.S. to employ certain foreign workers. Bill Gates claims the cap on H1B visas makes it difficult to hire employees for the company, stating "I'd certainly get rid of the H1B cap" in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-MarkRoy_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MarkRoy-80">[80]</a></sup> Critics of H1B visas argue that relaxing the limits would result in increased unemployment for U.S. citizens due to H1B workers working for lower salaries.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Campaign" title="Human Rights Campaign">Human Rights Campaign</a> Corporate Equality Index, a report of how progressive the organization deems company policies towards <a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a> (lesbian, gay, bisexual and transsexual) employees, rated Microsoft as 87% from 2002 to 2004 and as 100% from 2005 to 2010 after they allowed gender expression.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Criticism">Criticism</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:VistaParty3-cropped.jpg" title="File:VistaParty3-cropped.jpg">File:VistaParty3-cropped.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=BadVista&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BadVista (page does not exist)">BadVista</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Defective_by_Design&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Defective by Design (page does not exist)">Defective by Design</a> groups protest against <a href="/wiki/Windows_Vista" title="Windows Vista">Windows Vista</a></div></div></div>
<p>Criticism of Microsoft has followed the company's existence because of various aspects of its products and business practices. <a href="/wiki/Ease_of_use" title="Ease of use" class="mw-redirect">Ease of use</a>, <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/stability" class="extiw" title="wikt:stability">stability</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Computer_security" title="Computer security">security</a> of the company's software are common targets for critics. More recently, <a href="/wiki/Trojan_horse_(computing)" title="Trojan horse (computing)">Trojan horses</a> and other exploits have plagued numerous users due to faults in the security of Microsoft Windows and other programs. Microsoft is also accused of locking vendors into their products, and not following and complying with existing standards in its software.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Total_cost_of_ownership" title="Total cost of ownership">Total cost of ownership</a> comparisons of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Linux&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Linux (page does not exist)">Linux</a> as well as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mac_OS_X&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mac OS X (page does not exist)">OS X</a> to Windows are a continuous point of debate.
</p><p>The company has been in numerous <a href="/wiki/Lawsuits" title="Lawsuits" class="mw-redirect">lawsuits</a> by several governments and other companies for unlawful monopolistic practices. In 2004, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> found Microsoft guilty in a highly publicized <a href="/wiki/Anti-trust" title="Anti-trust" class="mw-redirect">anti-trust</a> case. Additionally, Microsoft's <a href="/wiki/EULA" title="EULA" class="mw-redirect">EULA</a> for some of its programs is often criticized as being too restrictive as well as being against <a href="/w/index.php?title=Open_source&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Open source (page does not exist)">open source</a> software.
</p><p>Microsoft has been criticized (along with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yahoo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yahoo (page does not exist)">Yahoo</a>, <a href="/wiki/AOL" title="AOL">AOL</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a> and others) for its involvement in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Censorship_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Censorship in the People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">censorship in the People's Republic of China</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> Microsoft has also come under criticism for <a href="/wiki/Offshoring" title="Offshoring">outsourcing jobs</a> to China and <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> There were reports of poor working conditions at a factory in southern <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> that makes some of Microsoft's products.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Corporate_affairs">Corporate affairs</span></h2>
<p>The company is run by a <a href="/wiki/Board_of_directors" title="Board of directors">board of directors</a> made up of mostly company outsiders, as is customary for publicly traded companies. Members of the board of directors as of June 2010 are: Steve Ballmer, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dina_Dublon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dina Dublon (page does not exist)">Dina Dublon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bill_Gates" title="Bill Gates">Bill Gates</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raymond_Gilmartin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raymond Gilmartin (page does not exist)">Raymond Gilmartin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reed_Hastings" title="Reed Hastings">Reed Hastings</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maria_Klawe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maria Klawe (page does not exist)">Maria Klawe</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Marquardt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="David Marquardt (page does not exist)">David Marquardt</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles_Noski&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles Noski (page does not exist)">Charles Noski</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Helmut_Panke&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Helmut Panke (page does not exist)">Helmut Panke</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MSPR-Board_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSPR-Board-89">[89]</a></sup> Board members are elected every year at the annual shareholders' meeting using a majority vote system. There are five committees within the board which oversee more specific matters. These committees include the Audit Committee, which handles accounting issues with the company including auditing and reporting; the Compensation Committee, which approves compensation for the CEO and other employees of the company; the Finance Committee, which handles financial matters such as proposing mergers and acquisitions; the Governance and Nominating Committee, which handles various corporate matters including nomination of the board; and the Antitrust Compliance Committee, which attempts to prevent company practices from violating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antitrust&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antitrust (page does not exist)">antitrust</a> laws.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Microsoft_5-Year_Stock_History.svg" title="File:Microsoft 5-Year Stock History.svg">File:Microsoft 5-Year Stock History.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Five year history graph of <a href="/wiki/NASDAQ" title="NASDAQ">NASDAQ</a>:&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nasdaq.com/symbol/msft">MSFT</a> stock on July 17, 2013<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>When Microsoft went public and launched its <a href="/wiki/Initial_Public_Offering" title="Initial Public Offering" class="mw-redirect">initial public offering (IPO)</a> in 1986, the opening <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stock&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stock (page does not exist)">stock</a> price was $21; after the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trading_day&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trading day (page does not exist)">trading day</a>, the price closed at $27.75. As of July 2010, with the company's nine <a href="/wiki/Stock_split" title="Stock split">stock splits</a>, any IPO <a href="/wiki/Share_(finance)" title="Share (finance)">shares</a> would be multiplied by 288; if one was to buy the IPO today given the splits and other factors, it would cost about 9<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nbsp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nbsp (page does not exist)">Template:Nbspcents</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Allan_2001_5-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Allan_2001-5">[5]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rp (page does not exist)">Template:Rp</a><sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MSSTOCK_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSSTOCK-93">[93]</a></sup> The stock price peaked in 1999 at around $119 ($60.928 adjusting for splits).<sup id="cite_ref-stocksheet_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stocksheet-94">[94]</a></sup> The company began to offer a <a href="/wiki/Dividend" title="Dividend">dividend</a> on January 16, 2003, starting at eight cents per share for the fiscal year followed by a dividend of sixteen cents per share the subsequent year, switching from yearly to quarterly dividends in 2005 with eight cents a share per quarter and a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Special_dividend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Special dividend (page does not exist)">special one-time payout</a> of three dollars per share for the second quarter of the fiscal year.<sup id="cite_ref-stocksheet_94-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stocksheet-94">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dividendfaq_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dividendfaq-95">[95]</a></sup> Though the company had subsequent increases in dividend payouts, the price of Microsoft's stock remained steady for years.<sup id="cite_ref-dividendfaq_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dividendfaq-95">[95]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Yahoo-MSFTchart_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yahoo-MSFTchart-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>One of Microsoft's business tactics, described by an executive as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Embrace,_extend_and_extinguish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Embrace, extend and extinguish (page does not exist)">embrace, extend and extinguish</a>," initially embraces a competing standard or product, then extends it to produce their own version which is then incompatible with the standard, which in time extinguishes competition that does not or cannot use Microsoft's new version.<sup id="cite_ref-eee_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eee-97">[97]</a></sup> Various companies and governments sue Microsoft over this set of tactics, resulting in billions of dollars in rulings against the company.<sup id="cite_ref-Orlowski2004-03-05_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Orlowski2004-03-05-98">[98]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-usvms_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-usvms-30">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-euantitrust_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euantitrust-35">[35]</a></sup> Microsoft claims that the original strategy is not anti-competitive, but rather an exercise of its discretion to implement features it believes customers want.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Financial">Financial</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Standard_and_Poor%27s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Standard and Poor's (page does not exist)">Standard and Poor's</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Moody%27s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moody's (page does not exist)">Moody's</a> have both given a AAA rating to Microsoft, whose assets were valued at $41&#160;billion as compared to only $8.5&#160;billion in unsecured debt. Consequently, in February 2011 Microsoft released a corporate bond amounting to $2.25&#160;billion with relatively low borrowing rates compared to <a href="/wiki/Government_bonds" title="Government bonds" class="mw-redirect">government bonds</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>For the first time in 20 years <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple Inc.</a> surpassed Microsoft in Q1 2011 quarterly profits and revenues due to a slowdown in PC sales and continuing huge losses in Microsoft's Online Services Division (which contains its search engine <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bing (page does not exist)">Bing</a>). Microsoft profits were $5.2 billion, while Apple Inc. profits were $6 billion, on revenues of $14.5 billion and $24.7 billion respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup>
</p><p>Microsoft's Online Services Division has been continuously loss-making since 2006 and in Q1 2011 it lost $726 million. This follows a loss of $2.5 billion for the year 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
