</p><p>On July 20, 2012, Microsoft posted its first quarterly loss ever, despite earning record revenues for the quarter and fiscal year, with a net loss of $492 million due to a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Writedown&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Writedown (page does not exist)">writedown</a> related to the advertising company <a href="/w/index.php?title=AQuantive&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="AQuantive (page does not exist)">aQuantive</a>, which had been acquired for $6.2 billion back in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of January 2014, Microsoft's market capitalization stands at $314B,<sup id="cite_ref-Marketwatch_MSFT_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marketwatch_MSFT-104">[104]</a></sup> making it the 8th largest company in the world by market capitalization.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3>
<p>In 2011, <a href="/wiki/Greenpeace" title="Greenpeace">Greenpeace</a> released a report rating the top ten big brands in cloud computing on their sources of electricity for their data centers. At the time, data centers consumed up to 2% of all global electricity and this amount was projected to increase. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Phil_Radford&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Phil Radford (page does not exist)">Phil Radford</a> of Greenpeace said "we are concerned that this new explosion in electricity use could lock us into old, polluting energy sources instead of the clean energy available today,"<sup id="cite_ref-Dirty_Data_Report_Card_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dirty_Data_Report_Card-106">[106]</a></sup> and called on "Amazon, Microsoft and other leaders of the information-technology industry must embrace clean energy to power their cloud-based data centers."<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> In 2013, Microsoft agreed to buy power generated by a Texas wind project to power one of its data centers.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>Microsoft is ranked on the 17th place in <a href="/wiki/Greenpeace" title="Greenpeace">Greenpeace</a>'s Guide to Greener Electronics (16th Edition) that ranks 18 electronics manufacturers according to their policies on toxic chemicals, recycling and climate change.<sup id="cite_ref-Greenpeace_International_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Greenpeace_International-109">[109]</a></sup>
Microsoft's timeline for phasing out <a href="/wiki/Brominated_flame_retardant" title="Brominated flame retardant">BFRs</a> and phthalates in all products is 2012 but its commitment to phasing out PVC is not clear. As yet (January 2011) it has no products that are completely free from PVC and BFRs.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>Microsoft's main U.S. campus received a silver certification from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leadership_in_Energy_and_Environmental_Design&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (page does not exist)">Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design</a> (LEED) program in 2008, and it installed over 2,000 solar panels on top of its buildings in its Silicon Valley campus, generating approximately 15 percent of the total energy needed by the facilities in April 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-news1_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-news1-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p>Microsoft makes use of alternative forms of transit. It created one of the worlds largest private bus systems, the "Connector", to transport people from outside the company; for on-campus transportation, the "Shuttle Connect" uses a large fleet of hybrid cars to save fuel. The company also subsidises regional <a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_transport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public transport (page does not exist)">public transport</a> as an incentive.<sup id="cite_ref-news1_111-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-news1-111">[111]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> In February 2010 however, Microsoft took a stance against adding additional public transport and <a href="/wiki/High-occupancy_vehicle_lane" title="High-occupancy vehicle lane">high-occupancy vehicle</a> (HOV) lanes to a bridge connecting Redmond to Seattle; the company did not want to delay the construction any further.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>Microsoft was ranked number 1 in the list of the World's Best Multinational Workplaces by the Great Place to Work Institute in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Marketing">Marketing</span></h3>
<p>In 2004, Microsoft commissioned research firms to do independent studies comparing the <a href="/wiki/Total_cost_of_ownership" title="Total cost of ownership">total cost of ownership</a> (TCO) of <a href="/wiki/Windows_Server_2003" title="Windows Server 2003">Windows Server 2003</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Linux&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Linux (page does not exist)">Linux</a>; the firms concluded that companies found Windows easier to administrate than Linux, thus those using Windows would administrate faster resulting in lower costs for their company (i.e. lower TCO).<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> This spurred a wave of related studies; a study by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yankee_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yankee Group (page does not exist)">Yankee Group</a> concluded that upgrading from one version of Windows Server to another costs a fraction of the <a href="/wiki/Switching_barriers" title="Switching barriers">switching costs</a> from Windows Server to Linux, although companies surveyed noted the increased security and reliability of Linux servers and concern about being locked into using Microsoft products.<sup id="cite_ref-Foley_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Foley-116">[116]</a></sup> Another study, released by the <a href="/wiki/Open_Source_Development_Labs" title="Open Source Development Labs">Open Source Development Labs</a>, claimed that the Microsoft studies were "simply outdated and one-sided" and their survey concluded that the TCO of Linux was lower due to Linux administrators managing more servers on average and other reasons.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>As part of the "Get the Facts" campaign, Microsoft highlighted the <a href="/w/index.php?title=.NET_framework&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title=".NET framework (page does not exist)">.NET</a> trading platform that it had developed in partnership with <a href="/wiki/Accenture" title="Accenture">Accenture</a> for the <a href="/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange" title="London Stock Exchange">London Stock Exchange</a>, claiming that it provided "<a href="/w/index.php?title=High_availability&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="High availability (page does not exist)">five nines</a>" reliability. After suffering extended downtime and unreliability<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> the LSE announced in 2009 that it was planning to drop its Microsoft solution and switch to a Linux based one in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2012, Microsoft hired a political pollster named Mark Penn, whom the New York Times called "famous for bulldozing" his political opponents <sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> as Executive Vice-President, Advertising and Strategy. Penn created a series of negative ads targeting one of Microsoft's chief competitors, <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a>. The ads, called "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Scroogled&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scroogled (page does not exist)">Scroogled</a>", attempt to make the case the Google is "screwing" consumers with search results rigged to favor Google's paid advertisers, that <a href="/wiki/GMail" title="GMail" class="mw-redirect">GMail</a> violates the privacy of its users to place ad results related to the content of their emails and shopping results which favor Google products. Tech publications like Tech Crunch have been highly critical of the ad campaign,<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> while Google employees have embraced it.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cooperation_with_the_United_States_Government">Cooperation with the United States Government</span></h3>
<p>Microsoft provides information about reported bugs in their software to intelligence agencies of the United States government, prior to the public release of the fix. A Microsoft spokesperson has stated that the corporation runs several programs that facilitate the sharing of such information with the U.S. government.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following media reports about <a href="/w/index.php?title=PRISM_(surveillance_program)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PRISM (surveillance program) (page does not exist)">PRISM</a>, NSA's massive electronic <a href="/wiki/Mass_surveillance" title="Mass surveillance">surveillance program</a>, in May 2013, several technology companies were identified as participants, including Microsoft.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> However, in June 2013, an official statement from  Microsoft read:
</p>
<blockquote>
We provide customer data only when we receive a legally binding order or subpoena to do so, and never on a voluntary basis. In addition we only ever comply with orders for requests about specific accounts or identifiers. If the government has a broader voluntary national security program to gather customer data, we don't participate in it.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup></blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Logo">Logo</span></h3>
<p>Microsoft adopted the so-called "<i><a href="/wiki/Pac-Man" title="Pac-Man">Pac-Man</a></i> Logo", designed by Scott Baker, in 1987. Baker stated "The new logo, in <a href="/wiki/Helvetica" title="Helvetica">Helvetica</a> italic typeface, has a slash between the <i>o</i> and <i>s</i> to emphasize the "soft" part of the name and convey motion and speed."<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> Dave Norris ran an internal joke campaign to save the old logo, which was green, in all uppercase, and featured a fanciful letter <i>O</i>, nicknamed the <i>blibbet</i>, but it was discarded.<sup id="cite_ref-Osterman2005-07-14_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Osterman2005-07-14-129">[129]</a></sup> Microsoft's logo with the "<i>Your potential. Our passion.</i>" tagline below the main corporate name, is based on a slogan Microsoft used in 2008. In 2002, the company started using the logo in the United States and eventually started a TV campaign with the slogan, changed from the previous tagline of <i>"<a href="/w/index.php?title=Where_do_you_want_to_go_today%3F&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Where do you want to go today? (page does not exist)">Where do you want to go today?</a>".</i><sup id="cite_ref-wherego1_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wherego1-130">[130]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-potentialpassion1_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-potentialpassion1-131">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Reimer_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reimer-132">[132]</a></sup> During the private MGX (Microsoft Global Exchange) conference in 2010, Microsoft unveiled the company's next tagline, <i>"Be What's Next."</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-2010logo_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010logo-133">[133]</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 23, 2012, Microsoft unveiled a new corporate logo at the opening of its 23rd Microsoft store in Boston indicating the company's shift of focus from the classic style to the tile-centric modern interface which it uses/will use on the Windows Phone platform, Xbox 360, Windows 8 and the upcoming Office Suites.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> The new logo also includes four squares with the colors of the then-current Windows logo.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> However this logo is not completely new - it was featured in <a href="/wiki/Windows_95" title="Windows 95">Windows 95</a> commercials from the mid-1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">

</p>

		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">

</p>

		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Microsoft logo &amp; slogan 2011-2012.svg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>2011–2012
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Microsoft logo and wordmark.svg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>2012–present
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
</ul>
</div>
<ul>
<li> <b>1987</b> - Microsoft "<a href="/wiki/Pac-Man" title="Pac-Man">Pac-Man</a>" logo, designed by Scott Baker and used from 1987 to 2012 with the 1994–2002 slogan <i>"<a href="/w/index.php?title=Where_do_you_want_to_go_today%3F&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Where do you want to go today? (page does not exist)">Where do you want to go today?</a>"</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-wherego1_130-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wherego1-130">[130]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-potentialpassion1_131-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-potentialpassion1-131">[131]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <b>2006–2011</b> - Microsoft logo as of 2006–2011, with the slogan <i>"Your potential. Our passion."</i><sup id="cite_ref-potentialpassion1_131-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-potentialpassion1-131">[131]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <b>2011–2012</b> - Logo by Microsoft with the slogan <i>"Be what's next."</i><sup id="cite_ref-2010logo_133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010logo-133">[133]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <b>2012–present</b> - Introduced on August 23, 2012, to symbolize the "world of digital motion" and Microsoft's "diverse portfolio of products".<sup id="cite_ref-newlogo_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newlogo-138">[138]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
